PREFACE
The following interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's
collection of oral testimonies. Rights to the interview are held by the United States Holocaust
Memorial Museum.
The reader should bear in mind that this is a verbatim transcript of spoken, rather than
written prose. This transcript has been neither checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy, and
therefore, it is possible that there are errors. As a result, nothing should be quoted or used from this
transcript without first checking it against the taped interview.

ALICE TYROLER
May 8, 2013
Beginning File One

segments.question: This is a United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mrs. Alice Tyroler — how do I say your last name?
segments.answer: Tyroler.

segments.question: Tyroler — on May 8", 2013, in Queens, New York. Thank you. Thank you finally for agreeing to share your story, share your experiences. I know that it’s not a — an easy or very pleasant thing to do, but we really appreciate it. And I want to start our interview wi — at the beginning. I’d like to ask you when you were born, where you were born; that is, your date of birth, your mother and father’s names, and if you had any siblings, tell me about their names and where in the family order you were, whether you were the youngest, or the oldest, and so on.
segments.answer: It will be quite simple, because my parents were both only children. So my name is Alice Tyroler, I was born on December 23", 1926 in Bratislava, which was at this time, Czechoslovakia. And my father’s name was call — Colemon(ph), or Calmen(ph).

segments.question: Calmen(ph).
segments.answer: Isela.(ph)

segments.question: Isela(ph).
segments.answer: Isela(ph). And my mother’s name was Anna Isela(ph), kay — born Fisher. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 4 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013

segments.question: Uh-huh, she — her maiden name was Fisher.
segments.answer: Her maiden name was Fisher, yeah. And —

segments.question: And your maiden name was Isela(ph).
segments.answer: Isela(ph), yeah. And —

segments.question: Did you have brothers and sisters?
segments.answer: I had one brother, by the name of Korp(ph). He was born on — was born on January — oh, I forgot now. I think it was the 12", 1924.

segments.question: So he was older?
segments.answer: Yes, about three years.

segments.question: Okay. And tell me a little bit about your family life. What was your father’s profession? How did he keep the family —
segments.answer: My father — my father had a store in Bratislava, which was — imported material for suit and men’s and ladies’ clothing —

segments.question: Textiles, uh-huh.
segments.answer: — he imported textile. He imported material from eng — England and also Scotland, and also from Czechoslovakia, was bought from Berlin and sent to various factories.

segments.question: And did — was he a textile merchant, or was he somebody who actually pre — made the suits of clothes?
segments.answer: No, he wasn’t that, he was importing it and selling it. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: Okay, and others made the suits.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They were tailors and the client would come and buy the material, or call my father up and said, Herr Isela(ph), I need a suit for this [indecipherable] occasion, because he knew him already. And so he would pick and show it to the person, and sometimes recommend a tailor.

segments.question: Okay. Did you ever work in the store —
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: — or did you visit in the store?
segments.answer: Oh yeah, I —

segments.question: Yeah?
segments.answer: — we visited as children, but I was too young at the time —

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: — to work 1n there.

segments.question: What kind of a place was it, the store?
segments.answer: The store is still existing today. They now sell some china in the store. It’s in the old city of Bratislava, and it’s in the middle of the city, it was a very nice area.

segments.question: Was it something your father bought, or had it been something that had already been established before him? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. segments.answer: It had been established, and he bought it from his boss, where he started learning the business.

segments.question: I see, okay. And what was the name of the store?
segments.answer: The name of the store is stoffhandlung, not-nothing special. [indecipherable]

segments.question: Was it called Isela(ph)?
segments.answer: They called it a stoffhandlung, what stoffhandlung is —

segments.question: Well, textiles.
segments.answer: Textile — textile store.

segments.question: Okay, so he didn’t have like his family name on there.
segments.answer: I really don’t think so.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But he was known there, because it was many, many years over there.

segments.question: And — excuse me — tell me a little bit about your mother.
segments.answer: My mother was born in Vienna, and she was in the fashion business. She has learned it, and when she came over to Bratislava, her mother stayed in Vienna and kept the store. It was a store also in fashion. My grandmother had the store, yeah.

segments.question: And —
segments.answer: Her father died very early. He had studied [indecipherable] University, but he died very early, died in his early 40s.

segments.question: That’s your grandfather, mm-hm. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: Yeah, he died in his early 40s.

segments.question: Did you — did you know your grandparents?
segments.answer: I knew my grandmother, the one from Vienna.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: My father’s parents were no longer alive when I was born.

segments.question: I see. What was your language at home? What language did you speak with one another?
segments.answer: German.

segments.question: And did you ever speak Yiddish, or was that just not part —
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: No, it was not.

segments.question: Okay. Were —
segments.answer: But I did learn later on in life, in France.

segments.question: Yeah. Were your parents, would you say they were assimilated into —
segments.answer: No, they were — they were Jewish. They were — it was called neologen, which is something like conservative here.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: So they belong — The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: We had the kosher home.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And because both of my parents worked, we had the nanny. And the nanny —

segments.question: Took care of —
segments.answer: — was there to take care of us, yeah.

segments.question: Was she — she — was she a local person?
segments.answer: She was from Sudeten-Deutschland, I don’t know.

segments.question: So she was German?
segments.answer: She was German, and Roman Catholic. Very religious person, and very nice person.

segments.question: Was she someone you were very close to?
segments.answer: Yes, we were very close to her.

segments.question: And were you close also to your parents?
segments.answer: Very much so, yes.

segments.question: Di — was there one that you felt a little bit closer to than the other?
segments.answer: Not really.

segments.question: Okay. What were their personalities like, your mother and your father?
segments.answer: I think they were very nice people.

segments.question: Were they extroverts? Were they shy?
segments.answer: No. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: Were they sociable?
segments.answer: Yeah, very sociable, they had lots of friends. And — but, for example, the store was closed on Saturday, but they reopened at night. So the Saturday was spent at home, and then they would go to a café house, I don’t know what you call it.

segments.question: A coffeehouse. A coffee house.
segments.answer: A coffeehouse with — meet with friends and pay the next day. So they were —

segments.question: So this way they would enjoy their Sabbath —
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: — but they did not break any rules.
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That was a kosher home and we went to the Orthodox temple because my father liked the place better.

segments.question: Did you go regularly?
segments.answer: [indecipherable] didn’t go, but he went more, specially for the high holidays, and usually during a regular year, there were local little places where one went to pray on Friday night, or — so he took us with him.

segments.question: Tell me, did you speak Slovak at all?
segments.answer: Yeah, a little bit, but —

segments.question: A little bit. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: — I’m fluent, of course, but we did not use it at home.

segments.question: What was the — what was the social situation like in Bratislava between the wars? Did people interact with those — let’s say, did you have associates of friends who were not Jewish, apart from the nanny, or were —
segments.answer: Oh, of course.

segments.question: Ah, okay, okay.
segments.answer: I went to a — the first school, the first five years, I went into the so-called Neologen Schule, which was the conservative school, where boys and girls went together to school, and from there on I went into the German gymnasium.

segments.question: Oh, these were public schools, or was the first one a religious school?
segments.answer: No those were religious school, but — yeah.

segments.question: But the German gymnasium was a public school?
segments.answer: Public? I don’t know what you call a public school.

segments.question: Something where a —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: —a school where children of various backgrounds —
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: — whether they were — yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And sponsored by the state, basically. That’s what it 1s. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.answer: Probably, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah. And did your parents socialize with people who weren’t Jewish, who were
segments.answer: Yeah, they had friends.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. Did — oh —
segments.answer: I went — by the age of 12, I was about 12, it was in 1938 when Hitler came to Vienna. My mother picked my old grandmother up and brought her over to us.

segments.question: We’ll come to that. I want to fill — still ask —
segments.answer: Sorry.

segments.question: It’s okay. I still want to ask a few questions.
segments.answer: You can erase it or something.

segments.question: No, no, no, this is fine. I want to ask you a little bit about your brother.
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: What — he was a few years older.
segments.answer: Three years older.

segments.question: Three years older.
segments.answer: Yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: And what kind of a person was he? Was he somebody who played with you as a little sister, or did he try to — was he a boy who just didn’t find girls interesting?
segments.answer: We were most of — yeah, we were quite close, and he was a very good reader, and he was in charge of my — my mother told him, you tell her what to read, and —

segments.question: Oh really? Yeah —
segments.answer: —I can read — I could read what I read, yeah. He was very generous, so —

segments.question: Was he a studious person?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. What were some of his interests as a child?
segments.answer: He has various interests, mostly — most of the things are read — reading. He also went to the German gymnasium, of course, earlier than I did, so he went longer. And I stayed only til the second grade, then I — they wouldn’t let me come any more because I was Jewish.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So, I went one year into another gymnasium, which was teaching not — there was not German, it was mixture between Czech and Slovak. And there I was a year.

segments.question: I forgot to ask, did you speak Slovak at home? I mean, Czech at home as well? Did you know Czech?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No, just Slovak. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Just German.

segments.question: Yeah. And — but did you know the Czech language?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay. Is it very different from Slovak?
segments.answer: Yeah, Czech is more like closer to the Polish language, and Slovak more to the Russian. It — it’s a little different.

segments.question: Uh-huh. Did you speak any other languages?
segments.answer: Yes, we spoke French. We had the private tutor at home. And at this time, unfortunately, wasn’t English that he taught us, but it was French. And she was there from, I think when I was — we started when we were seven years old, I was seven. My brother already had started earlier, and I only had to, for a few years, because couldn’t go on.

segments.question: Tell me, was your family well-to-do? Would you have considered them a well-to
segments.answer: Middle class.

segments.question: Pardon?
segments.answer: Middle class.

segments.question: Middle class. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: Middle class, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: They were not rich, but comfortable.

segments.question: Did you have — by comfortable, did your parents, for example, own a car?
segments.answer: No, they did not.

segments.question: Okay. Did they have a radio?
segments.answer: Oh yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: More than one.

segments.question: Yeah?
segments.answer: Yeah, that — but we spent Saturday night —

segments.question: Listening to the —
segments.answer: — 1n the dark —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — detective stories.

segments.question: Ooh.
segments.answer: Yeah, it was dark, and it was very exciting.

segments.question: Well, tell me about some of your memories ah — if you have an earliest memory. Do you have an earliest memory from your childhood?
segments.answer: Oh, I have the very pleasant memories until a certain time, and then we had to watch when we went out to school.

segments.question: Yeah, we’re gonna get there.
segments.answer: Because it was difficult.

segments.question: Yeah, we’ll — we’ll — oh, I lost my train of thought for a minute.
segments.answer: You'll find it.

segments.question: Who are some of your friends from school?
segments.answer: Mixed.

segments.question: Cl — anybody particu —
segments.answer: — in the beginning —

segments.question: Yeah?
segments.answer: — in the beginning, in the — the first five years, they were mostly Jewish children, because we went to a Jewish school. Later on it was mixed.

segments.question: Okay. Did you have a best friend?
segments.answer: I more than one. I don’t know exactly.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: And how were you as — growing up? Were you a quiet girl, or were you more outgoing? Did you like playing, tomboy, or more studious and quiet?
segments.answer: I think 1t was more quiet, and I like to read, and jump rope, and we started very early with swimming. I don’t know if you know that, but in Europe the sport that we had was gymnastic, and swimming.

segments.question: Much more — mu — much more emphasis on individual sports, rather than team sports?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay. When y —
segments.answer: Gymnastic, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah. When you were still a child, before the war, was there discussion of anti- Semitism? Did you feel it? Was it something that was in the air? Was it something you experienced —
segments.answer: Not before I was 10.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I don’t remember before I was 10, no.

segments.question: Okay. But after 10? That would have been in 1936. Did you sta —
segments.answer: We heard the radio, sure.

segments.question: You heard about it? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: We heard about it, yeah, they talked the radio about it, what’s going on in Germany [indecipherable]

segments.question: Okay. Okay, so what’s going on in Germany, but not necessarily in Slovakia?
segments.answer: There was nothing going on over here.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We’re just fine.

segments.question: But did people — people who were Gentile, did they — were there — were there normal relations, or did you ever hear or experience where people talked about some kids who would say things, or — or grownups who would be prejudiced, or so —
segments.answer: Not — not before —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — when everything turned around.

segments.question: All right. Well, so, ve held off til now —
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: — but let’s — yeah —
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: — let’s — let’s go there, let’s go to that part.
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: You mentioned earlier that — that in 1938, your mother brought your grandmother from Vienna to Bratislava. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Why’?
segments.answer: Because Hitler occupied Vienna.

segments.question: How — what happened — what happened to her? How did that affect her? Was her store closed, was it —
segments.answer: Well, she obviou — she must have locked the door and walked away.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: My mother took her over to us, and she stayed with us.

segments.question: Did she talk about what it wa — had been like in Vienna when he annexed Austria?
segments.answer: She was before already, back and forth, it’s very close.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I don’t know if you know, it’s just across the Danube. And — but the final holding was in ’38, I think.

segments.question: So, in those years, from ’36 onwards, you started hearing about what was going on in Germany. How did — was this discussed at home?
segments.answer: We also — yeah, we also saw already things change in — in Slovakia.

segments.question: In what way”?
segments.answer: In ’38, there were already Hitlerjugend, there was Bund Deutsche Madchen about th — The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: In czech — in czecho — 1n Slovakia.
segments.answer: Yeah, in Bratislava, yeah. And they didn’t like us. They insulted us. We didn’t take it as an insult.

segments.question: How did the —
segments.answer: We were proud of it.

segments.question: How did this express itself? Did they come to the store, did they not —
segments.answer: No, not to — not as far as I know, not to the store or anything. But what happened, for example, we were in the Zionistic organizations, and when you had to go home at night, you had to watch out.

segments.question: Were you scared?
segments.answer: My brother — my brother came home with bloody nose [indecipherable]

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Were you ever confronted on the streets?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Many times?
segments.answer: No, not too many time, about —

segments.question: Can you tell us a little bit about that, 1f you remember.
segments.answer: They were most — mostly tr — calling names and insulting, and there was the Bund Deutsche Madchen, and [indecipherable] The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: So you — so you would walk by, and somebody would see you, and they would call out something?
segments.answer: Yeah, and this — and I didn’t go out at night at this time. We didn’t — I mean, the girls didn’t [indecipherable] didn’t go out by it — herself.

segments.question: And your — when you came home, would you tell your parents about what was going on, what you had experienced?
segments.answer: Not if I didn’t have to.

segments.question: And reason why’?
segments.answer: Wasn’t pleasant. Why make them unhappy as in — they were already”?

segments.question: So in some way you were protecting them?
segments.answer: I don’t know, I mean —

segments.question: Uh-huh. What were the discussions at home about all these changes?
segments.answer: For example, at a certain time, we started — there was a swimming club. They started it — I started it, I think I was seven, to train real — a real thing, and it was called Bakhovka(ph). They still — we are still in contact with some of the people who still alive. And so we could do it til after a certain [indecipherable] I don’t know the date.

segments.question: That’s okay.
segments.answer: I have no idea about the date.

segments.answer: Gymnastic was private also. Also ended because we had other things on — on our mind.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So-

segments.question: So, I mean, the swimming club is something you were forced to leave, or your parents decided it was too risky?
segments.answer: I don’t know, I think they stopped it.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I really don’t know. I haven't thought of those things in about 80 years, so — or 75 years.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: That’s a long time.

segments.question: Yeah. Did you notice that — if your parents were more nervous than they had been before?
segments.answer: It was very unpleasant.

segments.question: I guess what I’m trying to get a sense of is whether or not what was going in the outside world, affected the world within the private world of the family?

segments.question: Mm-hm, a trolley car.
segments.answer: Trolley car. And they beat him, and we s — we saw it from the window, and couldn’t do anything. This is something that I remember.

segments.question: What was the name of his store?
segments.answer: Brishla(ph).

segments.question: Brishla(ph).
segments.answer: Brishla(ph).

segments.question: Tippihandlu(ph)?
segments.answer: Tippihan — Tippihandlu(ph) Brishla(ph), yeah.

segments.question: Tippihandlu(ph) Brishla(ph). And what street was it on? Because if 1t was across the street from yours —
segments.answer: I think it was Durament(ph), I’m not —

segments.question: Durament?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: I’m not quite sure. We had to leave before — on [indecipherable] where we grew up, up to about — when I was about 10, there we had the second floor of an house.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And was it a large place?
segments.answer: [indecipherable] Think it was six or seven rooms.

segments.question: That’s pretty spacious.
segments.answer: Was a bedroom, children’s room, dining room [inaudible] like a —

segments.question: Master bedroom.
segments.answer: [indecipherable] no.

segments.question: Uh-huh. Herrenzimmer, yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah, with books and — and everything. And then was a guest room, when somebody came. I think was ne — before, next to the children’s room was Nanny’s room, Nanny’s room. segments.question: Did your mother have any other, or did your family have any other help at home besides the nanny”?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Was there a housekeeper?
segments.answer: There was a cook, and a maid.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They lived in the house.

segments.question: Okay. How — did relation —
segments.answer: And they had — they had — no, they were not Jewish. About — when we had Hanukah, they had in their room a Christmas day. My mother made sure of that, yes.

segments.question: That’s very nice.
segments.answer: So they can —

segments.question: Celebrate —
segments.answer: — celebrate their holidays, yes.

segments.question: Yeah. As these changes were going on, for the worse, did things change?
segments.answer: They had to leave, sure.

segments.question: They had to leave.
segments.answer: My mother was not allowed to have.

segments.question: Okay. Did your nanny have to leave as well? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. segments.answer: She had to leave, but she left only officially. She took an apartment somewhere not far away, but she spent the days with us anyway.

segments.question: So her attitude, and her relations didn’t change with — for you?
segments.answer: Oh, no.

segments.question: Okay, okay.
segments.answer: Ol no. You will hear towards the end, what happened.

segments.question: Okay, okay.
segments.answer: She saved my mother and my brother in her apartment with her sister, during the whole time.

segments.question: Oh my.
segments.answer: And she knew if they caught her, she will be shot with them, okay?

segments.question: Okay, okay.
segments.answer: So — but it was in — that was already in 1945. So she was all the years with us.

segments.question: That’s am — that’s amazing.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: That’s amazing.
segments.answer: She was like an aunt.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: She was no employee.

segments.question: Yeah. Tell me what — how things developed further, as the 30s come to a close. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.answer: As ‘30 comes to a close, we had to move to another apartment again, because this was no longer available for — for Jews.

segments.question: So — oh, so it was a rented apartment?
segments.answer: It was always — we only had the apartment, we did not own a house.

segments.question: Okay, okay. And did you have to move to a different neighborhood?
segments.answer: Well, not a bad neighborhood, but a different neighborhood, yeah.

segments.question: And it’s at this point that your nanny no longer stayed with you? That is —
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Yeah, okay.
segments.answer: But she was there always.

segments.question: Do you remember the date that Hitler annexed Czechoslovakia?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: I believe it was in 1939. I think 1t was March, but I’m not sure.
segments.answer: ’'m not sure of that.

segments.question: Okay. But how did that ki — how did that resonate in Bratislava, when that happened?
segments.answer: The Slovaks were different from the Czechs.

segments.question: Okay. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: The Czechs stayed against the German. The Slovaks greeted them with pleasure.

segments.question: Why’?
segments.answer: The president of Slovakia was a Catholic priest, who was very happy and cooperative with — with the Germans.

segments.question: How do you explain that?
segments.answer: I have no idea.

segments.question: It’s so diametrically different.
segments.answer: I have no — yes, yes.

segments.question: How did this — how was this experienced on a personal level?
segments.answer: Very unpleasant.

segments.question: Did — what happened to your father’s business?
segments.answer: My father’s business was arizeered(ph)?

segments.question: Aryanized.
segments.answer: I don’t know, I don’t know.

segments.question: Ar-Aryanized, yes.
segments.answer: Aryanized, yes? I don’t know exactly when and how, I just don’t remember.

segments.question: Do you remem —
segments.answer: It was not important enough for me.

segments.question: Yeah. Was there a change in him?
segments.answer: I don’t think so. He was a born optimist. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: Was he?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: What would he say when things like this would happen?
segments.answer: It won’t last long. He did not want to leave Bratislava because he said, these people are all my friends, they’re not going to do anything to me. And it was very surprising.

segments.question: Well, tell me about some of that.
segments.answer: I don’t know exactly the time, but they came to — they came to get me once for the first time for it, but I was ill. I had a infectious disease, so they didn’t come in. So if — they came a second time. They took me and my mother and took us to — to the police. And from then on, to Novaky, to the camp.

segments.question: Had — had Czechos — had Slovakia already declared its independence?
segments.answer: I don’t know how it worked. I really don’t know how it worked.

segments.question: Okay. Do you remember —
segments.answer: I wasn’t interested.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: I don’t know if you understand what I mean.

segments.question: Oh yeah.
segments.answer: It was, who cared? And they were willing to sell us, supposedly was the only head of the state supposedly, I don’t know if it’s true. That’s what I heard. Then Dr. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: What a — what a betrayal. Do you remember how those guards looked when they came to get you?
segments.answer: They were Slovaks, Slovaks. Was called Hlinka, Hlinka guard.

segments.question: Okay. Were they young?
segments.answer: Yeah, I think so.

segments.question: And what was their manner like?
segments.answer: They brought us to the police, and there were all kinds of our friends over there already sitting.

segments.question: How old were you?
segments.answer: How old was I? That was in — I think I was almost 16.

segments.question: So it was in ’42?
segments.answer: Yeah, it was in ’42. I had in the meantime, after school, my father had a very good friend who had a bakery, including like a patisserie, where people would have tables. It still exists today in Bratislava.

segments.question: And which chi —
segments.answer: It’s called Konditorei Mayer. They were German, but very nice. They were friends of my parents, cause they had about four stores away from my parents’ store. And so when they throw me out of school, I don’t know if you’re interested in that — The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: Yes, I want to know about that.
segments.answer: When they threw me out of school, what do you do at the home all day long? So, this friend of mine, the — the ha — the Uncle Mayer, they called him, told my father, why don’t you let her come, and she can learn in my bakery, to — to bake and to cook, etcetera.

segments.question: And did you do that?
segments.answer: And then I — yeah. And when my father came with the idea home, I said, why should I go to learn to bake and to make hors d’oeuvres — you know, the very noble, elegant things? What do I need it for? So he said, when you’re going to have later on a cook, cook in your house, then you can supervise better, and you’re going to know how to do things.

segments.question: Did that make sense to you?
segments.answer: No. Now, or then?

segments.question: Then.
segments.answer: No. But it was better than hanging around doing nothing. So I worked there for a few month then.

segments.question: Mm-hm. But just a few months?
segments.answer: Yeah. About a year, or something like that.

segments.question: Mm-hm. And what was the experience like?
segments.answer: Very hard work, learning very, very nice things. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: Can you still make them?
segments.answer: Yeah, if I wanted to, but —

segments.question: You don’t want to.
segments.answer: — not now, nah.

segments.question: Nah. Did — at that point, was — in Slovakia, were you forced to wear yellow stars?
segments.answer: Yes, the big one.

segments.question: Okay. And when did that come in, fairly —
segments.answer: I don’t know.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I really don’t know.

segments.question: But fairly soon after all of the changes?
segments.answer: I think so, yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But I can find out those things for you whatever you — whenever you need it.

segments.answer: And then I had a third year in the other one, in the mixed one.

segments.question: In the mixed one.
segments.answer: Czech and Slovak, yeah.

segments.question: And that was okay, to go there, it was allowed?
segments.answer: Yeah, oh yeah, of course. And in the meantime, of course, we had organized — there was a very well-known bookstore in Bratislava, it was called Der Steiner. Steiner Buchhandlung.

segments.question: Steiner Buchhandlung, uh-huh.
segments.answer: Yeah. And they had the big house, summer home, with a garden, which had a fence. And they allowed all of those young groups of Jewish children to do whatever they wanted in their garden, because we saw that we couldn’t go there, because they would beat us up in — you cou — would walk up about 10 minutes. It was a very nice area, and there were the summer homes.

segments.question: And was this bu — was this bookstore owned by a Jewish —
segments.answer: Steiner familie, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah. Jewish family, yeah.
segments.answer: Yes. All that — about 200 years.

segments.question: What was going on — uh-huh? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: One of this — one the — one of the sons of the owner went with me to school, and we went to school, and he died about almost two years ago, in Jerusalem. He was working for Yad Vashem —

segments.question: Oh really?
segments.answer: — when he retired, yes. His name was — in Hebrew was David, but we called him Ziggy. Siegfried Steiner.

segments.question: Siegfried Steiner.
segments.answer: Yes. And his sister was Rially(ph) in Hebrew, and she was the [indecipherable] the leader of the group of Jewish children which I belonged to.

segments.question: Did you —
segments.answer: We would meet there, and talk there, it was all Zionistic organization.

segments.question: What was the name of the organization?
segments.answer: What was the name of the organization? One was — one was Maccabee Hatazair, that was mostly the sport. Bakhovka(ph) was the swimming club, and then was — I think it was B’nai Yehuda(ph), I’m not sure. Aki — B’nai Akiba.

segments.question: B’nai Akiba.
segments.answer: B’nai Akiba, | think, yeah.

segments.question: What was going on with your brother with the — all these things that were happening?
segments.answer: My brother had his group, where he belonged to. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But the Steiners were very good friends of ours. The parents were friends, and we were friends with the family. By the way, the sister, Rially(ph) Steiner, she died very early in Auschwitz. We know that. And then was there a — a very good friend of my brother’s, his name was Leo Lachner(ph). He died a few years in Switzerland, he was a — I think he was a composer in Switzerland. They were old friends. I don’t know if [indecipherable]

segments.question: It — it’s fine. I-I mean, the more names you can recall, the better it is.
segments.answer: Oh, I can —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: My — my — the first and second year was the — we had one main teacher in deut — in deut — in gymnasium. It was called the Deutsche Statzial(ph) gymnasium, and his name was Dr. Erbian(ph) Goy(ph), and he was very, very nice to us.

segments.question: And he was German?
segments.answer: I don’t know what he was.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Probably. He taught in a German gymnasium.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.question: So, were there Slovak people who showed that they didn’t like what was going on, or were there —
segments.answer: I don’t know, we didn’t — I don’t — didn’t have much contact with —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — with people.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We tried to survive.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: And learn.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But when we had these [indecipherable] in the — the garden, or ever we were, was mostly reading, and studying. Then came two teachers, two young women from Berlin, refugees. They survived, and they came to — and they started a religious school for the few girls over there, that was also in Steiner garden.

segments.question: So it was a refuge.
segments.answer: It was a refuge, yes, yes. I was still in contact with his wife. I was in very close contact with him til — til he died. He lived [indecipherable]. His cousin was — was in the store til the end, til now.

segments.question: I don’t understand that very well, he was in a store?
segments.answer: His cousin. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: Stayed in Bratislava.

segments.question: And owned a store?
segments.answer: And owned the store, yes.

segments.question: Store.
segments.answer: The same Steiner Buchhandlung.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: Yeah. There are books about them. I’m sure of — I’m sure there are in washing — in your museum.

segments.question: Well, it’s important to know about this from different people, and different sources.
segments.answer: Yeah, but I mean there — I’m sure there are.

segments.question: Yeah, okay, okay.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: When you were arrested with your mother, were your brother and father left behind?
segments.answer: They were not home.

segments.question: So they would have taken you all?
segments.answer: Yeah, they would have taken anybody they saw.

segments.question: Okay. And when they took the two of you, you left an empty house? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: This is a continuation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mrs. Alice Tyroler.
segments.answer: [inaudible]

segments.question: Yeah. And we were talking about — we were talking about the requisition and the confiscation of — of your family’s personal items. Can you tell me about the process, and how that took place?
segments.answer: I don’t know, they just made an announcement, you have to bring it there and there, and you took and you brought it.

segments.question: Did you do this yourself?
segments.answer: Iremem — no, I didn’t do it.

segments.question: Okay. What 1s it that you remembered?
segments.answer: I remember that I missed the radio very much, because there were no TVs or anything. And well, whatever jewelry there was, and good things, pictures, and you know, something.

segments.question: What was — what happened to you after you were at that police station?
segments.answer: After the police station, they took us on the train, and took us to Novaky.

segments.question: And what is Novaky?
segments.answer: Novaky was a camp that had — was a forced labor camp, and also selection, some — they went sometimes both to Auschwitz from there too. segments.question: I see. Did you know about those selections at the time?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Did people know where they were going?
segments.answer: We had an idea, yes.

segments.question: Okay. So, this was in 1942?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Had by that time you heard about what was happening to the Jews in other countries?
segments.answer: Oh shu — yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They were — I mean, I don’t know what you would call them in English, they were [indecipherable] they took messages from one place to another one. I mean, the whole world knew what was going on. Here they knew what was going on.

segments.question: When — how was your mother when you got to Novaky? You were together?
segments.answer: Yes, we were together for a short while.

segments.question: Who too —
segments.answer: My father and my brother stayed here in — stayed there.

segments.question: In their home?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Uh-huh, they were hiding.
segments.answer: In Nanny’s — in Nanny’s home, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And he was working also for — that was illegal, something illegal, Jewish organization, my brother. And my father was an expert, and he was hired by a company that belonged to the state. That gave him the privilege to wear the little star. There were big yellow stars, and little stars. And the important, working — if he’s in — good enough to work, he had the privilege to work in very little star.

segments.question: And it — was it so that when you and your mother were arrested, that 1t was at that point that your father and brother went into hiding with your nanny”?
segments.answer: I think so, I don’t know —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — really, yeah.

segments.question: Okay. And you didn’t know what was going on with them because you were at the camp?
segments.answer: We had no idea, yeah.

segments.question: Okay. What was —
segments.answer: And after a while, my father got a permission to bring my mother out, and I was supposed to follow a week later. segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — somehow were —

segments.question: How were you able to do that when you were in the camp yourself?
segments.answer: We were able sometimes to send out the note.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: When you found somebody who will take it.

segments.question: How was your mother’s —
segments.answer: And he —

segments.question: Uh-huh, excuse me.
segments.answer: — he — my brother said then, you can’t come yet, you’Il come probably in a week or two, but we are not sure. We can’t get it in writing. So I really — we decided to tell my mother then the permission was promised for me to go, so she would go. And I — we'd — we — we were told then, if she doesn’t go now, we can’t go any more. She had to go first.

segments.question: And she eventually —
segments.answer: She eventu — she gave in, yes. Because if I can’t come a week later after her, then she would have spoiled the whole thing.

segments.question: Yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: But I wasn’t sure that I could go, and I — I was glad to get her out.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Because I knew when she’s out, she would be safe, because [indecipherable] was there, and they will do whatever they can. And I stayed, and I told her I really — was almost a lie, but I did anyway. So.

segments.question: So what happened?
segments.answer: She went home too, and she officially was able to live with my father and — over there.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Somewhere, I don’t know where.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They were not in hiding any more, because he had gotten the job.

segments.question: What about your brother? Was he included in that safe — safety net, or —
segments.answer: I don’t think so.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He was in — he had to make his own.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But they were somehow in contact, but he had to make his own. We never talked about the time, never, after the war or anything, never. It was too painful. segments.answer: I was very happy that my mother was out. I was free to do whatever I wanted. I was working underground anyway.

segments.question: So why don’t you tell me a little bit about that underground work?
segments.answer: Underground is nothing much, it’s the — for example, we had the — do you want to tape that?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Okay, let me think, I have to think about it.

segments.question: About the underground activities?
segments.answer: Yeah, I have to —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I heard about it, I was too young to do too much.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: There were mostly men in there.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And we had the connection with Auschwitz, there was one man who went back and forth, until they caught him.

segments.question: That’s quite amazing.
segments.answer: Yeah. I don’t remember his first name, his last name — we called him Helfgott(ph). The blond young man who spoke fluently German, and went back and The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. And one nice day he didn’t come back, so they caught him.

segments.question: Was he a guard, was he a prisoner?
segments.answer: No, he was one of us, yeah. There was, for example, they brought in, at the certain time in — I don’t know if you ever heard, there was a so-called Siestej prapore, which is the sixth division of Jewish soldiers. In order to go like to the military, everybody had to go. They wore green uniforms. The Jewish group wore black uniforms, and were doing the ugly and difficult work, digging and — well, that was it. And they came in in about 1943, they brought them — transferred them from the military into the camp.

segments.question: As prisoners?
segments.answer: No, as — yeah, as inmates from the camp. Never — never saw the pr — yeah, as a prisoner. Okay. So, there was a group of young men, and one of them came with typhoid from — but he didn’t come with his group of soldiers, he came from another camp, but that was a political camp, that was not a Jewish camp.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He was called Elaver(ph), and there they had political prisoners. And I knew — we knew his family — I knew from home his family, but he came alone. His father was a psychiatrist who was killed by one of his patients, but before. And his name The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. May 8, 2013 was Janko(ph) Sakay(ph). And you couldn’t bring him — didn’t bring him in the barracks, so they brought him in a tent.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And I—I took care of him. Wasn’t afraid of that.

segments.question: You didn’t catch the typhoid?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Did he — did he get better?
segments.answer: Yes. He became a editor of a newspaper.

segments.question: Underground newspaper?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: I mean, after the war.
segments.answer: Afterwards. After the war.

segments.question: After the war, okay. So tell me a little bit about your daily life in Novaky.
segments.answer: When the — when those soldiers came in, they came of — say about 200 — I really don’t know how many came over there. The camp was divided into three [indecipherable]. Okay, and there was barbed wire, like — like a camp. I lived on the third one, the third, on top. And there were over there, barracks for families. I was in the barracks for families because I came in with my mother. And then were the barracks for young men, separated. And the joke was I never went into the barrack. I didn’t — I wasn’t interested to go into the barrack with all the guys. And one day, in The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. I think the reason for it was, what they did in Theresienstadt, to — when somebody comes in, some Red Cross or something, they show them how good they treat the people. I don’t know. That was my interpretation, I don’t know. And over there, I was a gre — I was a very good swimmer, so — so we swam over there. And one day I heard — it was on the — I think it was on a Su-Sunday. Was after work, we were there, and I heard they had brought Gizzy(ph) Fleischman in there, okay? So I got up in the bathing suit with just like a robe, and I went after her to see if I can help her, because I knew she’s in trouble, because they — they held her separate in a prison.

segments.question: And — okay. How — who was Gizzy(ph) shl — Fleischman?
segments.answer: Gizzy(ph) Fleischman was the aunt of my brother’s best friend, who lived til about two years ago, in Australia.

segments.question: Okay. And how was she well-known, how was she famous?
segments.answer: She was very, very active in, as you saw, in that c-camp, in the underground.

segments.question: Okay. Do you know what her — role she played?
segments.answer: No. People didn’t talk. And I was too young. I was a [indecipherable] but she was already about 40 years old or something.

segments.question: So did you go, and did you find her?
segments.answer: Yes, I found her. I found her and I — they let me in, the guard, because she was being interrogated, and she was in a separate room held. segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: She was not 1n the barracks with the other people, because she was too important. And I made her — I met her, she was very happy to see me. And then I said, I see you tomorrow, and find out where you are and what’s going on, and see you — they didn’t let me stay very long. But she was being treated normally, I mean, not — and then two days later, she was gone. She was taken to Auschwitz. And this way, at the time when I went down, somebody else walked next to me, a big guy. It was my future husband — became my future husband. We met over there because he came in with his military, and his sister was married to a man — next to Novaky, next to the camp, was a city. There was a —

segments.question: What was the city?
segments.answer: Prievita(ph).

segments.question: Prievita(ph).
segments.answer: Prievita(ph), yeah. There was a liquor and marmalade factory, and he was the director there. The factory belonged to a Jewish family, they were called Hymar(ph), and my later brother-in-law, they were called Grott(ph). He was able to pay the guard off, my —

segments.question: This Mr. Grott(ph), was he Gentile?
segments.answer: No-

segments.answer: The Hymars(ph) were Jew, too.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They were also Jewish.

segments.question: But how was he able to stay and be director of that marmalade factory?
segments.answer: They let them stay for a while.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Because they exported.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: They let them stay. I don’t know what the deal was over there where it was, but they were there. Wasn’t official any more, but he was there. He was not officially the director any more, but he was. And he was there visiting because his sister was in camp with two boys. Her two boys were three and six years old. We brought them in 1968 here, because my sister-in-law took them into the home after, because these two boys, the mother with the two boys were caught and taken to be shot. But they did not shoot the boys, because the peasant who — there was one woman peasant, there were two little boys, nice looking, good little boys, with the mother, and they were going to shoot them three. And the peasant begged the German soldier, give me the boys, I don’t have any children. So they told her, take them. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: Oh my God.
segments.answer: The six year old remembered, the three year old doesn’t. So, now, are we finished with Novaky, or you want to hear more?

segments.question: Oh no, I — I want to know a little bit more.
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: I want to know —
segments.answer: Okay, I worked in two or three places. I worked in — there we made — we made the backpacks for the military, and then I worked in the kitchen a little bit. The more you worked, the less you were — the more they let you stay, okay. So, I wasn’t very scared, I — because I was young and stupid, so [indecipherable]. So I stayed there in the barracks, had a lot of good friends, and started to go out with this man I met on the way to the pool.

segments.answer: He didn’t follow me, he went on the same street, on the same road.

segments.question: Forced labor camp, okay.
segments.answer: With lots of — with lots of old people and children and whole families.

segments.question: This is a continuation of the interview with Mrs. Alice Tyroler, on May 8", 2013, and we were talking about your friend who became your husband later.
segments.answer: Paul.

segments.question: Paul. There was a doctor, you were saying, in Novaky —
segments.answer: No, there was a doctor in camp. His name was Dr. Schpera(ph). He was a local doctor, and when the camp was established, they, of course, made him the doctor over there. We did not have much medication, the joke was, it was iodine and aspirin, that you went to buy.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Because they didn’t give us much medication. And he went out every day on the bicycle —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — to — with the prescription, and whatever they needed, and came back. Besides they brought back the BBC news, every day, to the right place.

segments.question: So the camp was rather well informed.
segments.answer: Very well informed, yes.

segments.question: How many inmates were there, let’s say at its height?
segments.answer: I don’t know.

segments.question: Do you know approximately how many it had? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. segments.answer: Must be a couple of thousand. I can find out for you.

segments.question: Okay, it’s not a — okay, that’s fine. And what were you — you mentioned earlier that you made knapsacks there.
segments.answer: We ro — made knapsacks and they made all kinds of things. They made clothing, they made men’s shirts. Was many [indecipherable]

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So I, when I finished with my work, with one shift of that, I went to the shirt manufacturing department and folded them.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: I was good at folding shirts.

segments.question: Were there many fatalities, or ca — in Novaky?
segments.answer: No, not too many.

segments.question: Okay. And how did the guards treat the prisoners, or the inmates, however you would call —
segments.answer: No problem.

segments.question: No problem? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 59 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013
segments.answer: They didn’t give us problems, no. We lived — I mean, we behaved properly, and one thing that I remember, one of the girls who was ill, was there alone, about my age. She cracked up and she got hysterical, and —

segments.question: And what happened?
segments.answer: They took her out. Probably —

segments.question: So, in that kind of atmosphere, where, compared to other places, other enclosed areas, camps and so on —
segments.answer: It’s a— was — yeah, was one of the easiest ones.

segments.question: But then, how do you explain that your future brother-in-law’s sister is shot in front of her children?
segments.answer: She wasn’t in there. That was after — after we — the — that happened after —

segments.question: After what?
segments.answer: After the whole — the camp ended at some time.

segments.question: Oh, I see.
segments.answer: Yeah, sure.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: That was already in the mountains.

segments.question: I see. So how long were you in Novaky?
segments.answer: I was in Novaky from — I think it was July, or — July — I think it was July, I’m not sure, 42. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 60 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: To August ’44.

segments.question: Over two years.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Had you any news about what was going on with your own family at that time?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Absolutely not, no. Then the — what was I going to say? Okay, so we were already at that, and BBC news came 1n, and then in *44, in August ’44, there was the uprising of the partisans in Slovakia.

segments.question: This would have been the communist partisans.
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: The communist backed partisans.
segments.answer: I think so, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But internationally, we had Fr-French, we had Russian, we had all kinds of partisans.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: This time, they came and they worked on [indecipherable] and about 200 young men went out to stop the Germans — to stop the German tanks, so not too many came The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. And I think they knew that, but that’s what happened. And what we had, my future brother-in-law, from this factory —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — had access to trucks, and he gave — he lent two trucks to the partisan — to the group over there.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: They were mostly people who were in the camp. Very few partisans, they didn’t stay there, they brought it in, and disappeared. And we loaded the trucks with children, and older people, and my friend Paul and I went on — on — on a truck, on the top, with — with guns, and there was a — full of kids and older people. And we took them to Banska Bystrica, which was a place where —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — have you heard the name?

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Okay. There was — still free — there were partisans, they were in charge at this time. We brought them there, and they took care of them there. And they were shooting [indecipherable] away, so everybody jumped up and down, you know, every time they came over a plane —

segments.question: Yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 62 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013
segments.answer: — it took down as many people as we can, and in — that was in the city, next to the highway like those —

segments.question: Sort of the —
segments.answer: — big holes.

segments.question: Yeah. Sort of trenches that —
segments.answer: Tren —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Trenches, yes. And they — they were hiding there, and — and the plane didn’t see people [indecipherable]. And one time, the last time when I was on there, I had enough, I didn’t go down, I stayed on, and the — came down, flew over me. I saw him, he saw me and he didn’t shoot. German pilot.

segments.question: And you were right there in his target?
segments.answer: I was right there, yeah. So he was a decent guy.

segments.question: But yet, he was shooting other times? Or was it other planes?
segments.answer: I don’t know.

segments.question: You don’t know —
segments.answer: Who knows?

segments.question: — you don’t know, yeah.
segments.answer: Who knows, something flies over you.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 63 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013
segments.answer: He didn’t shoot me. So then we went into Banska Bystrica, the family of Poles had friends there, so we went with them in — they had a house there, so we stayed with them, and they took me along, because when we came out of the camp, we picked up Paul’s whole family.

segments.question: So you, more or less, was it like you broke out of that camp —
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: — or had the Hlinka guards disappeared? How did —
segments.answer: Yeah, they — they — they opened it when the partisans came in with the weapons, they opened the camp.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Everybody could go wherever he could.

segments.question: Okay, okay. So they were losing the war?
segments.answer: They were not lo — didn’t last long.

segments.question: Oh, okay.
segments.answer: Didn’t last very long. So we were in Banska Bystrica for — for a while, and one day there was a air raid, and Paul’s sister was going to try to serve tea, you know, like to the group of men sitting there. And it was dark, so she went instead of the steps up, she went to — the wrong way. Flew down the st — flew down the flight of stairs, broke the collarbone and the shoulder, but had a — May, June, July, au — three and a half months old baby. So I — I started taking care of the baby. Luckily, she was nursing. That’s all she could do. Put her in the sling — The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 64 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013

segments.question: And hold her.
segments.answer: Put her in a sling and it grew back. No doctor, nothing. Then we went from there, we tried to go in the mountains, if somebody let us in or not — I have also somewhere in my papers, and I might find it. When I find the papers, Ill let you know.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Okay?

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: There was a school principal in the village. This is all in the mountains. And he had the — he took us in for a couple of days, until we found something else. He took us in in the — behind 1n the [indecipherable] same school, the room behind the wall, he had two very badly injured partisans, French partisans, whom he saved the life, yes. Was a nine year old boy who had a s — her — his son. And he went for food and then the — yeah, and got quiet, didn’t say anything, because he knew. There were nine year old kids, non-Jews.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: One time I remember I went with Paul to look for another place, to another village. And as we walked up the hill, there were two guards with — with guns. And the question was [speaks German] Germans.

segments.question: Yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Alice Tyroler °° May 8, 2013
segments.answer: Soldiers. And of course we couldn’t understand. We’re not allowed to, I mean. We did not know [indecipherable] we knew. So just [indecipherable]

segments.question: Can I ask a question at this point? Would you say that you th — I don’t know how to phrase it, but some people just put it bluntly.
segments.answer: Bluntly.

segments.question: Did you look pa — did you look particularly Jewish?
segments.answer: Me?

segments.question: Yes, and Paul.
segments.answer: Paul not at all.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Paul was reddish blonde —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — six foot tall, and perfectly Slovak.

segments.question: So he could pass.
segments.answer: He went for — then we went to one overnight to a — to a peasant, to another family, and they let us stay overnight. And all of a sudden we heard shooting, and there was father and daughter. But [indecipherable] and the neighbors came running and said, did you hear the shooting? And a peasant to — said, don’t worry about that, they only shoot Jews, they don’t shoot our people. So they didn’t know who we were, we were just refugees. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. segments.question: Got it.
segments.answer: Another little thing that maybe doesn’t make sense to record, or something —

segments.question: No, it does make sense.
segments.answer: We had the baby carriage, with the little baby, four months old baby. And it was snow, was in the winter. And I pushed the ba-baby carriage, because they couldn’t — I mean, the —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Came by a German car with an officer, very nice guy. He got out of the car, he said, [speaks German here] You know, because he saw I could hardly push. He got back onto the truck and drove away.

segments.question: You could probably use some gasoline he’s — is what he said.
segments.answer: Yeah, but I — I’ve — I said — I was stupid, I didn’t know. I probably spoke —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: —more civilized German than him, but —

segments.question: Yeah, of course.
segments.answer: But that wa —

segments.question: You don’t give off that you do.
segments.answer: No, I couldn’t.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: That — that’s it. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 67 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Next what is? Next day we found a place where they would let us stay as Slovak refugees. They didn’t know we were Jewish.

segments.question: So here li — here’s another question so that I’m clear. At first you said it was you and Paul who was going from village to village, but it was also — it was a larger group of people.
segments.answer: Was his mother, his sister, her husband, the baby, and the two of us.

segments.question: Okay. His mother, brother, sister, baby — so, six of you.
segments.answer: I never counted.

segments.question: Doesn’t matter. But it — not just a couple. In other words, a family.
segments.answer: But we went out when we needed to go look for another place.

segments.question: I see. So you were kind of like the scouts.
segments.answer: Sometime, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Something like that.

segments.question: Okay. So can we consider that from August when — you know, the — the guards just opened the place of Novaky, you escaped, and now you were in some ways in hiding.
segments.answer: After we did what — after we did what was supposed to be done, yes.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Alice Tyroler °° May 8, 2013
segments.answer: Then we went for his family.

segments.question: Yeah, then you went for his family, and then you started hiding, from one place to another, I see.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay. So —
segments.answer: Then we went — there was a lit — there was another peasant who must have known, because he was very intelligent, and his wife didn’t know. They have a little baby the same as ours, and the baby was very sick. And what do you do with a little baby? You can’t find a doctor over there in the mountains, they — who knows where he was? So I— I decided to put it in — you know, they used to call it — in prison it’s umschlag. It was, you put somebody with high fever, a baby, in a sheet with lukewarm water, and it cools it off. Cause they didn’t have a bathtub to put it in.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And the baby got — got well. So there were then the two babies, our baby and their baby.

segments.question: And their baby.
segments.answer: What else can I tell you?

segments.question: How long did this wandering last?
segments.answer: The wandering lasted from August ’44 to April ’45.

segments.question: Wow. So a good eight months. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript.
