segments.answer: A few months.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: A good — over half a year.
segments.answer: Then we went to another one, I told you. Not as Jews, it’s just the Slovak peasants, who had to leave because there was something going on.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And there was something very interesting, because how do you have — yeah, somebody wa — became suspicious, and there was an old man, the — the patriarch of the family. And he was sitting in a room, and he called me in. And he started to ask me questions. Either he heard the language, and it wasn’t as good as the others or something. And I knew everything. I knew my name, from Alice we got Aloyasia(ph) — yeah, I forget to tell you then, in one of the villages, Paul went to the German Kommandatura and got papers for everybody.

segments.question: How was he able to do that?
segments.answer: He was a Slovak. He was a Slovak, so he gave him permission to go from one village to another one, for him and his mother and his — the whole —

segments.question: Okay. Okay. So he —
segments.answer: So he wa — he [indecipherable] papers, yeah.

segments.question: Okay. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Alice Tyroler ” May 8, 2013
segments.answer: But this — this old patriarch of the family didn’t seem to believe that. And he called me in a room and he asked me the questions and everything, and the holidays, which I knew exactly because I am very, very versed —

segments.question: So, Christian holidays.
segments.answer: Iam very well versed, yeah, because Nanny taught me. She wanted me to know every — both.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And — until he asked me one question. He asked me when my name day is, because in Europe —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — the — the religious Catholics didn’t celebrate so much the birthday, but the na — day of naming. Now, for example, my nanny was Anna. And this — heilig(ph) Anna was on July 26, I knew that every year, okay?

segments.question: And heiliga(ph) Alice?
segments.answer: [indecipherable] Aloyasia(ph), I have no idea. That’s how he caught me. So he sent — in a snowstorm he sent his son for the priest. The priest came in the night, through the snow. And the priest came, and he told him that this — she sam — she seems to be Jewish or something, she’s not a Slovak. She’s either a Gypsy or something, we don’t know. So the priest told him to let me go in a separate room with him, he will ask me. So we went there, and he said, I know who you — he told The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection Interview with Alice Tyroler m May 8, 2013 me, I know who you are, I know you are Jewish. If you can go now, tonight, in the snowstorm, out of here, the snow — you know, when you walk —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — okay, you usually leave a trail. But when it snows, it’s covered til the morning.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: The priest said, I do not have to go now to the German Kommandatura in the night, because it’s a snowstorm. If you disappear from here overnight, I will go in the morning and tell them where you are, in this house, but you’ll be gone. So that’s that. That’s what we did. That was when a Catholic priest saved my life, okay? So in a — what else, yeah. My father, while my mother was hidden with my brother at the nanny, was in — but that was before, a little bit.

segments.question: That’s okay, tell me.
segments.answer: He had a friend, a professor in the hospital, and he told him too he will hide him in the hospital, as a patient. You don’t see, I mean, you’re lying in bed, an older man. So he was there, and they came also — the SS came in and checked. And one of the people who came in was a young man who was originally from our house, the super’s son.

segments.question: Oh my.
segments.answer: Who my father found a job in [indecipherable] this carpet store, the oriental carpet store. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. This document should not be quoted or used without first checking it against the interview. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of oral testimonies. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 72 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: And he learned there the business. He was — he started as a — he — where you learn it —

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: — then you become higher and higher and higher. So my father was very happy, he saw him, he said, this one is not going to —

segments.question: Betray me.
segments.answer: — betray me. He took him, and out. He went to Sarrit(ph). From Sarrit(ph) he went supposedly to Auschwitz, and from Auschwitz he went to Oranienburg somehow. They don’t know if it was Oranienburg or Sachsenhausen. That’s what your papers show.

segments.question: And what happened to your father?
segments.answer: We don’t know. He died somewhere.

segments.question: And it was because —
segments.answer: A week before liberation, he was alive, that we know. Because a friend of his came back, and he told us. Then, he was still an optimist. He was telling, do you see the fla — see those planes are coming? You see the shooting, we can hear already, they coming to liberate us. And he — they went back, they went to sleep at night, and by the morning he was gone. And nobody knew where, if he tried to escape, or whatever, you don’t know. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. Information about access and usage rights can be found in the catalog record. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection 73 Interview with Alice Tyroler May 8, 2013

segments.question: And it was all because of this — this young man who —
segments.answer: Yeah, this young man we —

segments.question: — the super’s son.
segments.answer: Yeah, the young man who — yeah. And what else, I wanted to tell you something. Maybe I remember, if not, then — yeah. While we were in this one person’s house, who knew who we are, and hid us — [phone ringing]

segments.question: Excuse me just for a sec — [break] Okay, and we’re continuing. What were we talking about when the phone rang? I think it was that you — we were talking about your father, and —
segments.answer: We were talking about my father, yeah. And —

segments.question: Father, and the super’s son, who betrayed him.
segments.answer: Yeah. That was in ’44. And yeah, during ar — around Christmas, when we were in the person’s house —

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: — they had a son, and I ask him could he get me some kind of a card, because I wanted to send a Christmas card. They didn’t have Christmas cards, but like a postcard.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And I wrote to my nanny. I wished her a merry Christmas and told her [speaks German] that was me [German]. Yeah. That kay — what I had in mind — she knew The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. She knew it was me who wrote it, but they’re not going to come her, to interrogate her where I am.

segments.question: Oh my. You had to think so cleverly.
segments.answer: To survive.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: I didn’t want her to get in trouble, to —

segments.question: So, if I translate that, you — you sent her a postcard wishing her merry Christmas.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And then that — and then a message —
segments.answer: You do not have to — yeah.

segments.question: Look for —
segments.answer: Don’t look any more for —

segments.question: Lisa.
segments.answer: — Lisa.

segments.question: She’s shot.
segments.answer: She’s a— yeah.

segments.question: She’s been shot.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And — and so y-you’re — you were letting her know that you were not shot, that you were alive. Okay. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. It has not been checked for spelling nor verified for accuracy. segments.answer: I didn’t know then my mother was there, or my brother was there, but I knew she would be there.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And after the war, we came back to Beravita(ph), that’s where the aunt let them — left them there, and I went to look for my family.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Now, the trains were not going yet, because there were still mines on the —

segments.question: On the tracks.
segments.answer: Yeah, on the whole railroad tracks. So what we did, Paul and I — he went with me, to look for my family. We couldn’t go into the tr — into the train, but I don’t know what you call that in English, I never learn. Between two trains, the round things we — where they meet, the trains.

segments.question: You mean, there are — where the —
segments.answer: Buffers, or something like this.

segments.question: Bumpers? Sort of like bumpers between one car and another?
segments.answer: Between one — yeah, between, but big round ones.

segments.question: Okay. There must be — I— I understand what their function 1s.
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: Okay. So you were between two cars of a train? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: So we sat on this, because we couldn’t go in, because it was not official, there was not allowed to go in, because they were trying out the rails for mines.

segments.question: Oh, I see.
segments.answer: If there’s still mines.

segments.question: So this is after the war already?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay. So where did —
segments.answer: Was in April.

segments.question: Tell me, when did the war end for you?
segments.answer: When did the war end for us? Sometimes 1n beginning of April, I think.

segments.question: Okay. Is it be — was the — was the Soviet army there?
segments.answer: Yeah, the Soviet army, we had the very interesting meeting with the Soviet army.

segments.question: In what way?
segments.answer: We were still at the — that wa — that was before.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: We were still at the peasant’s house.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And when the Soviets came in, the peasants hid their wives where they kept the potatoes, etcetera, you know, because the Soviets like the ladies —

segments.question: Yeah. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: — very much. But I was in boots, and I didn’t look very — and so we — we took a chance.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And we went down to the highway to find out how we can move out of there. So there came a horse and wagon, with four Russians.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Two 1n the front with the horses, and in the backs, two officers. And we stopped them, like two hitchhike. They stopped, and we ask them — they could understand each other, so what [speaks foreign language]

segments.question: What does that mean?
segments.answer: Take us to the next village, maybe.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And the one officer — because you know they have those metal thingy, said, Yu(ph) yevreyka(ph)? That means, you are Jewish?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I figured the Germans didn’t catch me, now the Russians caught me. What now’?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And I said, Da. Ya(ph) Yevreyka(ph).

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And he — his answer was, ya tozhe Yevrey(ph). The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: Yup. I don’t speak Russian —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — but I understand, yeah [speaks Russian]

segments.question: [speaks Russian]
segments.answer: Parusku(ph), yeah.

segments.question: So what did — did he help at all, did he do anything?
segments.answer: Yeah, he helped, he gave us some bread and he took us and told us where to get off, yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He helped a little.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But he didn’t — I thought he would — he would kill us. But it was very interesting, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Ya tozhe Yevrey(ph).

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Then, I don’t know if you want to know anything else, I don’t think —

segments.answer: Went to — went to, from the train station, to Nanny’s house. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — walked up the stairs.

segments.question: And?
segments.answer: And there was my mother and my brother, in her apartment.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: They had no idea then I was alive.

segments.question: Did they get the postcard?
segments.answer: Yeah, she got the postcard, but that was months before. I mean, they didn’t know what happened to me afterward.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: So-—

segments.question: What a meeting that must have been.
segments.answer: Yeah, it was an interesting meeting.

segments.question: Probably more than just interesting. Did — when did you tell each other — did you talk about what you had all been through? Had your mother asked what those past years had been like?
segments.answer: I didn’t talk.

segments.question: You didn’t feel like it, you didn’t want to?
segments.answer: No, no. No, what, just to excite? And then my mother [indecipherable] room, and we got an apartment, he had a room in the same house — oh, and I didn’t want to get married, because I thought — my mother thought and my father is going to come back, was hoping. And I figured, she is sick, old and sick, and if my father comes home crippled or something —

segments.question: Who will take care of?
segments.answer: I didn’t want him to be stuck with — with a family like that. So we waited for quite a while, and then my brother started to work for the UNRRA in Hamburg.

segments.question: So he was — he went to Germany”
segments.answer: He went with a — with a group of Czech peop — Czechoslovak people to Germany for the UNRRA.

segments.question: Okay, and you s —
segments.answer: In British uniform.

segments.question: And how did you — and you stayed in Bratislava?
segments.answer: I stayed in Bratislava, yeah.

segments.answer: The UNRRA supplied him.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: The UNRRA supplied him, and he went to Hamburg, into the port, and he was — they gave him some high, official [indecipherable] and he met over there [indecipherable] daughter, they got married. In the meantime he went onto the Exodus.

segments.question: Oh, and he went to Israel?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: Exodus was over there in Hamburg for a while. He went on, and of course they caught him, and they wanted to — some punishment for English officer to go, and they knew he was a Jew. They English — the British. So the Czech consul got him out, they said he was a Czech. Czechoslovak citizen, you have no right to — he didn’t do anything, he didn’t kill anybody, he didn’t steal anything, and they got him out. And he called one day, and he said, I’m coming home. The UNRRA 1s being —

segments.question: Disbanded? The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. The recording is the primary source document, not this transcript. segments.answer: No, somehow transferred.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And I said no, you’re not coming home, because we knew, if these people come back, they will put him in jail, because they were now communists, they were under the British end. I — I was scared, you know.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I said, no you don’t. I take my mother. In the meantime, six weeks before that, we got married, because I said, if my father comes back, you’ll find him anyway.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I didn’t want to wait any longer, because the communists were there, and we didn’t know what’s going to happen. So I took my mother with her handbag, and we went on vacation, quote, unquote.

segments.question: And where was the vacation to? What place?
segments.answer: The vacation was originally supposed to be just a short vacation, just to look if we can get the — because we would have visas later for South America, we c- couldn’t come to America. We wanted to go to Israel. So I went, sat on a train with my mother, went to Paris.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And in Paris, we went into an immigration hotel where immigrants live. And I got a job, I was translating a little bit. segments.question: And this is when, what year?
Forty-eight. So, two or three years pa — had passed?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And —
segments.answer: We’re waiting for my father.

segments.question: To come back.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And you’d — did you know at that point that he had been sent from Auschwitz to somewhere else? You just didn’t know, he disappeared from the hospital.
segments.answer: We knew — the last month we knew that he was with his friend, and his friend saw him at night, and in the morning he was gone.

segments.question: Okay, so you knew that much.
segments.answer: Yeah, that much. And I thought when he didn’t show up in three years, but my mother wouldn’t give up.

segments.question: Of course, of course.
segments.answer: So-

segments.answer: There were some interesting things. My — Paul was working in the Bricha, and my brother was working in the Bricha, and what — what else? I was working. We worked parachutes, cut them up, and I painted them in scarves. I made scarves of them, and sold them.

segments.question: And that’s how you brought some money in?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Still the textile business.
segments.answer: No, that wasn’t textile, that was art. No, but —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — we bought the — bought the parachute, then you —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — cut them, and —

segments.question: Was it — was — was there a shortage of food?
segments.answer: Not much.

segments.question: Okay. Did you — where did you live during those three years?
segments.answer: In the house I wa — I was living before we went away.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: In the first house, not in the second house, in the first house.

segments.question: In the first house.
segments.answer: Yeah, in the same street where the Deutsche Statzial(ph) gymnasium was. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.answer: Everybody. To have to do it, you have to do it. Israel was very nice for us, for me, because we were free.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: — you don’t need anything, you have enough.

segments.question: Well, I— I have a — you know, just sort of like last questions, final questions. Is there anything that you think should be added to this, that you’d want people to know?
segments.answer: ... We were lucky. Most of us survi — of us survived. Was married for 50 years, have a very nice family. That’s my revenge.

segments.question: As I said, it’s a good revenge.
segments.answer: I think so.

segments.question: Yeah, I wanted to know from you, how come you so much didn’t want to talk about these things. And if you can give me the explanation, I would appre — I would really appreciate it.
segments.answer: I did not talk to my children about it, because I don’t think it should be — children need to know that, when they’re young. We have time later. And then, my basic idea is, there are two kind of people; people who have feelings and heart, and they’re going to get hurt by these stories; the people who don’t like us are going just to have pleasure from it, and I don’t want to give it to them.

segments.question: I can understand that. And it’s a complicated way to try and address that. The point where you say people who will clearly — children, when they hear things that their parents went through, they feel for their parents, and they want to —
segments.answer: Why hurt them?

segments.question: Well, it helps — they hurt for their parents.
segments.answer: Yeah, what for? What does it do now?

segments.question: It tells them who they were.
segments.answer: Remembering is important.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: But remembering — they hear enough about it, through all kinds of studying and literature, etcetera. The following transcript is the result of a recorded interview. segments.question: Okay, so let’s add on a few thought — final thoughts.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Why is it that after so many years, you finally decided that you would tell your story? Who prompted you to do so?
segments.answer: I was very lucky. I was married for 50 years, and I have three wonderful children, six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, and if — they were the ones, and also my — my nieces’ children — both nieces — and they were the ones who requested this a long time ago. But I never wanted to do it. But when I was in Washington, D.C., at this ceremony, I realized then they are right, and I was wrong, and I owe it to them to give that.

segments.question: It’s a real gift. And thank you for doing so.
segments.answer: Does it make sense?

segments.question: Yes, perfect sense. Thank you very much.
segments.answer: Thank you.

segments.question: And this concludes the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mrs. Alice Tyroler, on two thousand and — May 8", 2013, in Queens, New York.
segments.answer: Thank you very much.
